title: Adversary Trial Opinion 523(a)(2)(a) - Complaint itself based in Fraud
question: I was the debtor/defendent. I won the Adversary at Trial. My counterclaim against the Plaintiff included Fraud charges against him, based in his Fraudulent actions that were part of the original transaction and his fraudulent actions as the basis of his Adversary.
answers: It is unclear what the issue is. It seems that the adversary was regarding the dischargeability of the debt. If you won, then the debt is non-dischargeable. Is that the question?

My understanding of the circumstances is that you filed a BK, a creditor filed and adversarial proceeding to adjudicate your debt non-dischargeable on the basis of fraud, and you counterclaimed. You successfully defended the adversarial against you, and are looking to make your counterclaim based in fraud so that it “sticks” even if your creditor files a BK. Is my understanding of the facts correct?

The basic idea here is that the best practice is never to put words in a judge’s mouth, especially if the statement is something that the judge could interpret as an inaccurate portrayal of what they said. It is a practice that could potentially piss off a judge and cause you problems down the line, and moreover, it is unnecessary for you to do this in order to win your case.

Rarely, in the real world, outside of “Law and Order” or “Perry Mason,” is there a smoking gun in a case. Rarely does the defendant admit to murder on the stand in a fit of hysteria induced by a genius prosecuting attorney’s brutal cross examination. Cases are nevertheless won, and lost, everyday, without all of the drama and pomp and circumstance.

What I’m saying is, if you get a transcript of the trial, and the judge uses the phrase “not credible” in describing your opponent’s testimony, then those are the words you should use WHEN QUOTING or ATTRIBUTING statements to the judge. If you want to make a case for fraud against your opponent in pleadings or court documents that you file, then you are free to use that term and substantiate it with your own evidence and rationale. I would never, however, state that a judge held something that s/he didn’t explicitly state, because that very likely will get you into trouble, even if you were operating with good faith and sincerity.

Two other considerations here… First, did the judge make any official findings of fact or conclusions of law? Those official findings are the law of your specific case and can be relied upon. Second, why didn’t the judge write his own opinion in this case? Your question asks “Is this sufficient to include the word "fraud" in the written opinion…” Typically, attorneys will submit orders to the judge to be signed, but written opinions are written by the judge themselves. It’s hard to give a more precise answer without more precise information regarding the case and its status.

In short, I would steer clear of even marginally misquoting a judge in any written document. Nevertheless, whether or not a judge used the word “fraud” in their opinion in a case, you can make your own allegations of fraud and rely upon your evidence and your version of the facts to prove fraud notwithstanding. The judge doesn’t need to decry “fraud” for the facts to prove fraud.

These matters are complex, and in case you haven’t already done so, you owe it to yourself and your future to consult an attorney to attempt to ensure a good resolution to your matter.

I wish you luck in your pursuit of justice!

Based on the facts in your inquiry, the bankruptcy court appears to state the lack of credibility of the creditor, as a factor in your winning the adversary.

If the judge wanted to use the word fraud, the judge would likely have said so, and would have provided further facts to support such a finding.
In my opinion, fraud was not the issue, credibility was, of the creditor.

It more likely that any determination of fraud, would have to be made in the future, when that issue is an important factor to consider, and it was apparently not an issue in his actions in your adversary.

It is pure speculation if this creditor would file bankruptcy, and then you would have to prove a similar fact situation at that future time, as appears done in the just completed adversary action.
I do not see the connection, or persuasion to a later time, because there has not been a clear and definite determination established, at the present time in your case, of fraud by a creditor.

What there may be, is that parties may not plead inconsistently, or take inconsistent positions, from one case to another, about the same facts.

The judge granted your counterclaims? When you say you "won", did the judge make findings of fact that the other party actually committed fraud? Because a party is not credible at trial alone doesn't mean they are guilty of fraud.
